reviewText:
Perhaps not a game to start outside sales events because of lowish player count, but Blade Symphony is one of the more interesting fighting games I've played. It is more deliberate, slower, but also deadlier. A character with a moveset and sword dedicated to slow but damaging counter hits can kill you with a single blow if you screw up your offense. The round's outcome is not decided even if one player has 100% hp and the other has 1%.

The way the game controls is pretty unique, it's centered around a combo system with stances and utilizes kb+m so there's definitely a learning curve and it'll take a while before the feeling of jank wears off. But after enough training, you will understand the uses for all of the few dozen different swings your character can perform. Perhaps one move has a fake-out portion at the beginning that baits an attack only to counter it, perhaps it hits instantaneously at your side and catches the flanking opponent off-guard, maybe it makes you hop forward and thus extends your effective range, etc.

Because the game has a parry system that lets slower attacks deflect faster ones, the game is rather punishing against button mashing when you have even slightest skill difference between players. Mashing faster attacks is the same as almost begging your opponent to devour your HP bar with one decent counter, while slower attacks can leave you horribly vulnerable and are often not as good when your enemy is right within grabbing distance

If you got the patience to study a character's full moveset, it's definitely a game worth learning. It's the only fighting game I could call myself even remotely adept at thanks to the very different pacing

reviewText:
The closest thing to real life combat in a video game. The fun and thrills of a sword fight without the fear of an untimely death. Footwork, timing, anticipation, with a variety of moves from combos, charge attacks, dashes, jumpsm grabs and throwing knifes, This game embodies skilled one-on-one dueling where the better man truely wins.

I'm supprised at how complete it is for being a beta, there is no current meta despite there being 3 differant characters each with their own playstyle and sets of attacks, and four differant swords which have considerible differances in how you approach combat, everything feels fluent and natural, there is a viable counter to everything and every method of attack is just as viable. The game's unlockibles are purely asthetic, there are no items that change gameplay at all, so you can always be sure it's a fair fight.

Fantastic game, it really fulfills my pvp urge and leaves me feeling satisfied with my victories and humble in defeat, knowing that only my errors left me dead.

reviewText:
Amazing swordfighting game. Quick dynami and satisfying. It isn't too hard to learn and hard to master - as it should be.

There might not be as meny players as I would hope but you can still find a good match quite easily.

The only thing that could be better I think are the animations. They don't look as good or realistic as in some games but they do their job. They aren't so game-breaking.

Over all I would give it 7/10 (quite good, does what it should).

reviewText:
Last good swordfight sim I played was Bushido Blade for PS 1 and I really loved that game. Blade Symphony feels similar only downside is that it feels way more arcade.
I would love to have a realistic damage system disabling limbs, but I guess Bushido Blade was like nothing else.

I like...
...the 3 different stances that at least come a bit closer to actual swordfighting. (Even if most swordfighting techniques have more than just 3 stances.)
...the somewhat tactical swordplay in this game.
...the style of the characters and the modability of their appearance.(even if the mods out there are mostly retextures and nothing to breathtaking till now.)
...that the different swordtypes you have to unlock are purely cosmetic and you have the full arsenal at your disposal from the begining.
...you can see a hologram of how your sword will cut through the air in your current pose and the current direction of your swing. (Never seen that in another game before I think.)

I don't like...
...the arcady health bar, I would prefer a more deadly combat, maybe something with disabling limbs if hit.
...the look of most fighting places, they look somewhat cheap and packed together without much love for detail and looks.
...that there are way to less different gamemodes for this otherwise great game. There are only point capture, free for all and some duells availiable.
...the low player count.
...that some of the animations look awkward and unhuman.

For people who love swordplay/figthing this is well worth about 5 €. and if you buy it with friends I'm sure you can have a lot of fun cutting eachother to pieces. Buy it in the humble weekly bundle as long as it is there!

reviewText:
I haven't played this game for as much as I'd like to thus far, but it's pretty clear already how impressive it is.
Going through all of the tutorials gave me a grasp on the fighting system works. I understand the basics, but still can not reliably win in a duel for the life of me. This is and of itself isn't a bad thing. In fact, part of me is excited for how much more I have to learn. Unfortunately, another part of me is upset by the fact that there's no easy or convenient way to do so.

This game does not hold your hand. It very much tosses you into the deep end and lets you sink or swim of your own accord. If you've ever played 'Toribash', you'll probably understand what I'm talking about; you've got an incredibly complex fighting system that you can start with a friend to be on-par with (though only because neither of you are any good yet), or you can play against bots or foes online that understands the ins and outs of the system and as such, at least for a reasonable while, tend to beat you without contest.

The game makes a point of saying that it will include further tutorials at a later point, which would certainly be welcome because as it stands one has to figure out most of the mechanics by themselves after seeing somebody else do it. YouTube for now remains the best place for in-depth tutorials to be best of my knowledge.
In any case, this is definitely a game that will take a long time to master. If you're genuinely willing to spend many, many hours playing and perfecting this game, then good for you, I recommend it. I fear for many, though, it could end up sitting in their library as ‘that one game I really should really get better at some time’.

Character customisation is decent – you can chose one of four characters and one of a lot of swords, both affecting gameplay stats, and you can also make a few aesthetic changes. Unfortunately the character and sword you fancy most for the looks mightn't necessarily be the best for actual competition, but I find changing up your style to match a new, cool sword you unlock is refreshing.
The modding community is certainly not lacking - there are plenty of custom items and maps to download, if that's your bag.

I tentatively recommend this. I think you can already tell whether or not you'd be wasting your money.

reviewText:
I really didn't have high hopes going into this one, but after playing a few hours of this I'm really happy I picked it up. Blade Symphony reminds me a little of a soul calibur game. I'm really not even sure how you'd classify it. It manages to be super fast paced and exciting without sacrificing strategic gameplay. Stance dancing and combos flow together really smoothly, parrying requires good timing and foresight, and overall the combat feels great.

I've been told the community is pretty dead, and I suspect maybe the summer sale deals have caused things to pick up a bit. In my case, I found a server with at least 16 other people to play with within 5 minutes of starting up the game.

I kind of expected lag to make this kind of fast paced combat a complete ♥♥♥♥ show, but surprisingly few of my (very numerous) deaths have been lag related.

I'd definitely recommend this game, but if my experience is anything to go by, it'll take some time to learn the ropes so try not to get too frustrated.

reviewText: If you're persistent enough you can get good at this game, but there will come a time where you will find that whoever spams or glitches the best wins most fights due to glitchy tracers and poor netcode (lower ping usually always wins encounters). Can't really recommend it because there is practically no freedom to develop your own playstyle, you either copy what works or eventually lose out to it.

reviewText: So far I have fallen in love with Blade Symphony. It has its fair share of issues, but those are all outweighed by the excellent combat mechanics. There are four fighters all with very unique fighting styles, and strengths and weaknesses. There are also five different types of swords each fitting to different fighters in unique and interesting way. There are, however, some issues, for one, offline play There is an AI to practice against but it is incredibly bad, you have to set up what the AI will do, you can for example set it to attack or defend, it cannot do both, making it effectively useless. Also the player community is fairly small, which is sad, I have played ten hours so far and I have already run into some people I recognize repeatedly, but overall I love Blade Symphony's combat mechanics, and that's what sells it for me.

reviewText:
Its an interesting idea. You enter a map, and then you can either just go around fighting other players without restrictions (server-specific rules and etiquette may vary), or challenge them for a proper duel.

The graphics are nice and there are buttloads of custom content (thank you steam workshop for making installing them so easy).

As for gameplay, the swordfighting isn't as smooth as chivalry or mount & blade, and the jumps and parkour aren't as smooth as warframe (when its not lagging like hell or when you are not with a ♥♥♥♥♥on of alien dogs trying to get a piece of your ♥♥♥), but the gameplay is pretty damn solid.

If the only thing holding you back from buying this game is the price, wait for a sale.

reviewText:
Combat is fun and has enough depth to take a long time to master. Having the ability to roam is a nice touch and the challenging system works well. It feels like you're part of a community . . . Provided you log in when people are online.

I speak for the Australian region when I say that unless you log in at a specific time of day, you're never going to have anyone to play with. Even then,. you probably only get a window of one or two hours. The gameplay is great fun, but the lack of players makes it really hard to get into, especially when most of the playerbase are veterans.
I want to love this game but it makes it difficult for me to do so, especially with there being no Australian ranked servers, so unless I play on >300ms, I can't unlock any new weapons.

I'm going to recommend this game because it needs recommendations. The game is great. The community is friendly. But the sheer limited playerbase is what kills it, and a negative review won't help this game be what it should at all.

reviewText:
Blade Symphony does one thing and it does it well. This game is all about swordfighting. It is presented in a few rather similar formats. What must be understood is that it is not just another fighting game.
There is a somewhat hidden element of social interaction and importance of good manners. People have different opinions on the importance of manners, and some seem to deliberately be rude to get you off balance. Beating these people is immensely rewarding.
The best and worst part of this game is the heavy reliance on the community. The community does carry the game in every way it is lacking, but only when a decent number of servers are populated.
I'll leave ya with this: Bow before (and after) every fight, don't attack people who are typing and don't use shurikens. I will find you and I will play foul if you do. Otherwise; I'll see ya in-game for some sword-clashing!

reviewText:
This game... I have written a few reviews on this game.  Deleted them multiple times in the past.  Some were positive and others were negitive.  Why am I saying this?  Because I have a love hate relationship with this game.  It's good at what it does and when you find a playstyle you love it really comes alive.  (For me, this playstyle was shuffle shuffle shuffle and try to be sonic with a longsword)

The positive:
+Good combat
+Loyal community
+Variety of playstyles and options

The negitive:
-The game's population is made up of loyal players, but newbies are uncommon.  I highly recommend you DO NOT pick this game up if you want to fight against people of your own skill level all the time.  It is a small community and most of the people who make it up have been playing for a long time (like me, I've played since EA)
-Sort of toxic community.  You will find a lot of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s in this game.  A lot.  Not everyone is like this, but... yeah.  It's not as bad as Dota 2 or LoL, but it is still up there.  (You might find old reviews saying that the community is great, these are mostly from the SoW days.  The community changed and not for the better)
-Spamming... Well, the combat is good, just don't think that it doesn't allow spamming.  Spamming in this game can only be countered if you ACTUALLY TRY TO COUNTER THE SPAM.  Don't just think you can beat it with your normal style, you can't, you have to adapt to it.  Fighting masters, diamonds, and most steels is usually the best way to avoid spam, but low level play is made up of spam, almost to the point of exclusivity.

There are a lot more reviews out there that can talk more indept about the pros and cons of this game and its combat.  People who have played as long as me or longer.  However, I figured I would put this up because... well, just because.  BS has been an important game for me.  It is one of the few games I feel as if I can actually say I am good at (Not the best, yes, but I am somewhat good) and it does deserve at least a look by fighting or hack and slash fans.

Blade Symphony,Is a new game on Steam from Hack&Slash genre,Unlike Moun&Blade series it is based around 1v1 or 2v2 duels.The way you choose your attack type is quite similar to Mount&Blade,You swing your sword the way you move or rotate your camera therefore the use of attacks is quite easy.The diffrence in system thats used in Blade Symphony then Mount&Blade is that in Mount&Blade you used same attack all time but in Blade Symphony those attack differ due to combo boxes(Left bottom side of screen).
All attacks have three versions(Which is awsome for me) Tier 1,Which is uncharged attack,Tier 2,Which is half-Charged and Tier 3,Which is fully charged.Thanks to this all characters have huge variety of diffrent attacks.
This game is prefect for lovers of Swords,Acrobatics,Parkour and Combat.In this game all of those are in use for you.
So far there are four main characters(Hopefully there will be more) Judge(Knight),Phalanx(Gentlemen),Ryoku(Breakdancing Monkey) and Pure(♥♥♥ of steel).All four have completly diffrent play styles.
Judge is a heavy knight that got huge power but he is quite slow(On higher ranks he is annoying as hell).
Phalanx is a gentlemen that uses mostly stabs that stun lock any oponents.
Ryoku,Breakdancing Monkey,King of air cancels and air attack,Nearly everyone plays him due to over powered heavy straight.
Pure,Only Female character,To our surprise her chest is quite a regular size BUT that ♥♥♥ is so amazing.

Not talking about the few last patches that have over powered two characters and two swords,The game is great for a person who loves Sword fights,DON'T GET FOOLED BY THE VIDEO,You don't create your own fighting style but you create your own sequence in which you use the moves,It will still probably come down to meta but well...Remember kids,Don't do meta.

The Game itself is quite good.If I would have to give it score out of 10...Gameplay 8/10,Graphics 9/10,Story -/10(Who needs a story for Hack&Slash).So the verdict is,8.5/10.Its a great game I would recommend for anyone intrested in Swordfighting to purchase it!
Thanks for reading!

reviewText: Blade Symphony is a 3d fighting game that ditches the classic you're always locked onto your opponent" movement of most traditional 2d and 3d fighting games in favor of simply moving with the arrow keys/your controllers directional pad and aiming attacks with the mouse/your controllers analog sticks.\n\nThough I can see that it seems to be shaping up to be a solid game
date: and I appreciate more experimental fighting games that don't necessarily stick to Street Fighter styled controls
recommended: I'm not quite fond of the "stance" system. Basically
hoursPlayed: instead of having light/medium/heavy attacks
voteText: you instead have to switch between 3 different stances which alter your entire moveset. 1 is "light/fast"
helpfulPercent: 2 is "medium/medium" and 3 is "heavy/slow". Each of these stances is designed to be strong and weak against the other two stances in a classic rock/paper/scissors weapon triangle. While that's all well and good
votesHelpful: I still feel that having to roll over the mouse wheel to select from 3 stances in the heat of combat in order to get the move you want feels clunky and convoluted. I would have much preferred just having light/medium/heavy buttons. I mean seriously
votesTotal: imagine if in Street Fighter you had to roll over a damn mouse wheel or reach over to the number keys on your keyboard and than do a movement sensitive input every time you wanted to throw a damn sweep as Ryu.\n\nThere are a few other nitpicks with the combat
votesFunny: though I assume these will be tweaked out and refined with time. At the moment blocking seems to be pretty useless

reviewText: Blade Symphony, This game is absolutely incredible. The graphics of this game are on par if not better than any AAA title game this year. This game strives in realism, the combat and graphics alike. It is like being in a real life sword fight, as a medieval sword fighting enthusiast and reenactor I believe I have the expertise to say that this is a very realistic game. If you don't have the money to own a sword collection like myself this game is a great substitute, the swords on the workshop are all so realistic and people must of taken months if not years to design them.\n\nThis game is just incredible so many different game modes to play and so many realistic sword fighting moves/techniques to use, I love playing this in the winter as my fellow reenactors don't like going out in the winter. Thank you for making this amazing game I love every aspect of it, if you don't buy this game you will regret it for the rest of your life.

reviewText:
Blade Symphony harkens back to the classic Jedi Knight series, focusing on 1 on 1 sword duels.  If you were a fan of lightsaber duels in those games, you'll feel right at home here.  For the uninitiated, this is a rather unorthodox and very unforgiving fighting game, with a steep learning curve.  You will struggle over the nuances of the controls.  You will lose a lot of duels.

However, once you can get past the initial bumpiness, you'll find that there's a lot of depth.  What seemed random at first actually requires quite a bit of technique and timing.  The veteran players can be very friendly, and will be more than happy to provide advice.  Some servers will even hold impromptu classes for players who ask.

As for the Early Access Beta, the game is adequately playable.  There is one character that is still a work in progress, but the other characters have fully realized movesets.  There aren't a lot of game modes, but when the focus is on 1v1, this isn't a big issue at this time.

Post-release edit:  The gameplay itself is much more refined after several fixes and balance changes.  Pure's moveset has filled out nicely.  This is still a lean, mean fighting game; perhaps not the most feature filled (for now), but it certainly isn't lacking in depth.  Jedi Knight/Academy fans will be chuffed.

reviewText:
Blade Symphony is a 3rd person fighting game that throws button bashing out of the window...and like 3 continent's away.

In other words there is a lot of skill involved, but it's still very intuitive and quite easy to learn, though as you might expect, difficult to master.

Which brings me to my next and perhaps most important point, you guessed it, the community! The people playing this game are amongst the most helpful and fun to play with people I've ever played with in a multiplayer game.

Servers like School of War are often full of people who are willing to help those who are new to the game or who need it. It can be a lot of fun when people organize events and people are just very diciplined when it comes to following the rules and not to mention often really polite. Almost every duel I've fought begun and sometimes ended with a bow, even though that isn't necessary.

The game itself is definitely brilliant as well. At the time of writing the game is still in beta and the developers are constantly adding things to and refining the game. From the beautiful visuals and music to the incredible depth of the fighting systems, how duels play out and the customization.

Overall it's a very enjoyable experience playing this game and becoming better at it through practice or through help from fellow players.
It's a work in progress, but definitely something to look forward to.
---------------------------
5 months later, all of the above still pretty much holds true imo. The game has progressed quite a lot though, some would argue for the worse, but I personally like where it is going.

And on a little side note, for anyone who's interested, the developers of this game actually have a meeting every saturday at around 4 pm. PST or 12 pm. GMT, which they stream on youtube. Just search for 'punyhumangames' and perhaps subscribe if you want to get notified whenever they do one. I find it can be quite insightful and they will also answer any questions you post in the comments.

reviewText:
From my short experience playing this game, I think I have played long enough to review this game as poorly as possible.

I bought Blade Symphony after looking for a swordfighting little duel game for a while ever since I did some dueling in Dark Souls. Blade Symphony isn't Dark Souls, and it shouldn't be. It's unique and I like it for that.

Pros:
-Fast paced sword-swinging gameplay.
-Jumpy trampoline action
-Plethora of things to stab people with
-Spectator view to remind you how good the other people playing are and how bad you are at this game.
-Twirly spinny dancing moves

Cons:
-Fast paced sword-swinging gameplay.
-Jumpy trampoline action
-I suck at it
-Lovable characters that can't make witty one liners
-Decent gameplay and community
-Nice music
-Too many weapons
-Not Dark Souls

Overall score: 7.5 Pure's out of 10.

reviewText:
Ever since A Long Time Ago BC, or maybe around the middle of the Qing Dynasty, people have wanted to use swords. But until now, they couldn't. Now, they can.
Introducing Blade Symphony, the very first game that allows you to use a sword.
In this game, you take a sword, and you find opponents that are real people that  you probably wouldn't like, and then you challenge them to a duel, and then you get your ♥♥♥♥ handed to you on a pointy stick because you're bad at this.
To be good at blade symphony, you need be good at the game. That involves using all the different attacks you can use, and knowing when to block, which sword type you like, which character you think is the superhottest, and how that character does good things and which good things are good to do at certain points of the duel.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Game not worth $15 for the average joe. Save your money and wait till its on sale for $7 - $3

As you can tell by my playtime, I’ve played a lot of this game. Hundreds and hundreds of hours and thousands of duel matches. At the time of writing this my current ranked game number stands at 2594 Wins, and 1298 losses for a total of 3892 matches which is 11,676 individual ranked fights.

Eleven thousands individual fights, and for some reason I find myself warning you dear reader that this is not a $15 game. I purchased Blade Symphony back in December 2013 for around $7 dollars; my brother purchased the game for $3, and I can tell you right now based on the current game I overpaid.

So let’s start with the good: If I’m writing a negative review, then what is keeping me playing.

The Good

Workshop Integration:

The current game allows me to create (using various modeling and texturing programs) my own weapons and items. I am one of the more active and prolific workshop creators in this game. This is one of the main reasons I have continued to play this game, as I love to create custom items for people to use. Without this workshop Integration I would have quit the game a long, long time ago.

Deep Combat System:

This game has the framework for a fantastic combat system, giving you a true feeling of skill when you defeat an opponent. There is a lot of depth here.

And… that’s it for the good.

The Bad

This game has a severe lack of content in the form of game modes as well as characters. I personally have played only one of the four characters in nearly all of my 11,000 matches. The character I chose was unfinished as of December 2013, and is now being released unfinished in May 2014 (the game’s current release date). You heard me: This game is releasing an UNFINISHED character and charging you $15 for it.

There are currently only four characters in this game (or 3.5 considering the unfinished/unbalanced character I play. There is also only one way to play the game: 1v1 duel. This is the only game mode you will be able to play at launch and unless you have a competitive streak like me; you will eventually grow bored of this, as 99.98% of the current community has. This game currently has over 30,000 people who OWN the game, yet at peak times US East you will barely find 30 people playing.

The asking price for this game is $15, I urge you not to buy until it is at least HALF this price, or even a quarter of this price; because the vast majority of you will not be able to play this nearly as long as I have and you will likely quit within the first 5 to 10 hours once you’ve seen all this game has to offer. I want to reiterate; it was my Workshop projects that have kept me here so long, not just my competitive dueling.

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER : I don't fully recommend this game but I rated it up because the pro/con balance stays positive.
I'm going to be direct : if you don't like competitive/versus gameplay, just go away. This game isn't for you. No need to read the rest of the review.

Now, if you're still here, you might be interested.
Let's be honest, this game is HARD AS HELL when you're a beginner. The tutorial doesn't really help, there's no solo/bot play at the moment and the  only mode available is 1v1 Versus. There is no matchmaking, you are free to join the server you want. This is how, on my very first game, I fought against the 113th world's best player. No need to say I got REKT.
Despite the density (not easy to understand at first glance and not very intuitive controls) of the game and its little balance problems (just check the forums, but it's nothing that can affect you as a beginner) Blade Symphony remains pleasing.
I'm not the best versus player in the world, on the contrary actually... yet I won my first match after a dozen of fights which is not so bad and quite rewarding.
Nice addition : There's Worshop Content available for this game.

Finally, I'd say this game needs time to add what it lacks of and fix some issues. Just give it time.
I'm not going to rate this game /100 as I'm not a big versus player and I don't think I have enough knowledge of versus games to rate this accurately.

reviewText:
For the most part, I have trouble giving this game a thumbs up since I know after this weekend I probably won't be playing with people who started the time I did. With the learning curve being somewhat high; not too much though, and also it being a little tricky to understand, this fun I've been having could be very short lived.

Although that only being the case, I can't really see why not to pick it up. With it soon being 75% off and now maybe one having a taste of the game, this might spike up the players. The combat is very well classed right now of all the people you can choose from. Sure, sometimes spamming is the way to go and can be frustrating to deal with, but the game offers helpful strategies to bypass this. Then after a person learns to mix and match their fighting moves, they then learn which one they like the best.

With an interesting plot, good balancing that's simple, and nice play time to boot if there are players to play with, then this game is a must have for a fighter enthusiest.

reviewText:
At its very core, Blade Symphony is a simple game, and that's what makes it great.
The selection of characters is somewhat limited, but each one coupled with the different weapon types means that there are a multitude of options available to players right from the beginning.

Combat is relatively exciting as well, since you have to anticipate and respond to your enemy's selections and actions.
Every exchange is unique, as the attack-chain system allows you to combine multiple different stances into one, fluid attack.
Sure, there are some kinks in the system that need ironing out, but the overall feeling is that the developers have created a very polished game - even at this stage of development.

reviewText:
Long story short, Blade Symphony is a fighting game and a good one at that.  But a review is a review, so I'll delve into it more.

Blade Symphony is a traditional fighting game except the main attraction of it is, as in the name, blades/swords.  Every match is a 2-out-of-3 match.  Your main weapon in this is a sword.  You can do the classic moves of any fighting game, such as grabbing, block-breacking, doing combos, etc.  Also, you do have a projectile, a smaller blade you could say.  But here is a main strength of the game: you cannot spam.  Instead, to throw you projectile, you have to charge the throw.  This is a good feature, especially for fighting game nuts like me since anybody who has played a fighting game online knows there are annoying" experiances.  Not with Blade Symphony.

Anyways

The downside is that you are extremely slow and any medicore-timed hit can have the opposition racking up combos and defeating you quickly.  You'll have to know your opponents moves and have good timing to use this technique to your advantage.  And last but not least is fast.  Fast is all about speed. reviewText: Don't think so -- feels way too stiff, the camera angle is seriously terrible (I want to be able to see more of what my opponent is doing), and the stances/combos aren't nearly as intuitive or interesting as I'd like. The videos make it look like a combination of Soul Calibur and Toribash but the experience of actually playing the game is currently pretty crummy. That said, the big free-for-all matches look like they still have a lot of potential (I'd really love to be enjoying the game as much as I enjoy watching the last few minutes of the trailer), and the game seems fairly WIP, so I'm happy to give it a few dollars and more time to improve.\n\nHonestly, speaking as someone who plays console ports with a mouse and keyboard when he knows he really shouldn't simply because I can't be bothered to hook in a controller, one of this game's biggest problems could be that it's obviously designed around a mouse and keyboard. I'm not sure they can overcome that basic issue, but we'll see. More single-player content wouldn't hurt either -- the current tutorial is pretty light and doesn't compare favourably to playing the game online.

reviewText: It's a game with a bit of a learning curve but definately fun when you get the basics down. Chivarly is a bad comparison, yes it's based on swings and counters but the third person and mobility feels a lot different. I can compare it more to PvP darksouls when it comes to just how the game plays. The controls are a lot different though.  At the moment for an early access game it's surpisingly balanced, based mostly on your personal skill and experience with a character/sword combo. Of course there are a few things that seem a bit out of place. What's neat Is all the unlocks are simply cosmetic, and if you can't afford a new sword yet there are plenty in the steam workshop that not only allow you to see the swod differently, but everyone else in the game sees the same model as you do.

reviewText:
A fast way to describe this game is like Jedi Academy meets Bushido Blade.

If that isn't enough then the best way I can describe playing this game is with a story of my first win in a Duel.
There are two kinds of servers you can play on, Free For All servers where you can practice and talk to other players or Dual servers where you go one on one in ranked matches.

Whilst you are cued to fight you watch however is currently playing. The game operates on a Winner stays on" system so a good player can stay on for dozens of matches. That was what was happening this time I was playing. The player who was controlling the ring was using a rapier
date: a sword that can break through a players guard easily and get a lot of low damage hits in. He had completely wiped the floor with me the first time we fought and so I got to watch him fight three other players before I got another try.\n\nI spent that time watching his tactics
recommended: the Rapier is great head on but does almost no damage if you try to swipe with it
hoursPlayed: so he was forcing the other player to come at him from the front. Either by throwing knives at them when they hung back or by diving in himself. In a sword clash or parry the Rapier will almost always come out on top so he was able to take people down with ease. Over the three fights I watch I figured out a strategy to take him down.\n\nI was using the Tone Death
voteText: the first Longsword you get in the game which is good for wide sweeping attacks. When the match started we bowed and then I started to circle him
helpfulPercent: trying to get in a position where I could get around and past his guard. He didn't seem to be expecting it when I finally came at him and
votesHelpful: instead of meeting him head on
votesTotal: rolled past his guard and brought my sword round in a wide horizontal swipe that took of a good sized chunk of his health.\n\nThe rest of the first round continued like that
votesFunny: with me chipping away at his health until he finally fell. The second round started differently
commentsCount: he came right in on the attack
column16: striking at me and putting me on the backfoot. I rolled away as fast as I could to get away from his attack. I managed to land a few hits hear and there but he was hurting me more than I was hurting him. I was going to lose if that kept up\n\nCharging up for a fast strike which would take of a huge chunk of my health if it landed
column17: he came around for a final strike. You can shuffle back instead of rolling
column18: it doesn't carry you as far but also doesn't leave you vulnerable to attack. So I started shuffling like a 50's singer and managed to dodge all three of his attacks along with the follow up. In the moment after his attack I brought my blade down it a heavy vertical strike and took of the rest of his health.\n\nHis body slumped to the floor and I sheathed my blade as I let out a breath I hadn't even known I was holding. I don't think I have ever felt happier at winning a game in my life."

reviewText: Oh, how I love this game. I have always been a fan of swordfighting games, but there haven't been many that I loved so much as this one. This game has been on Steam since May of 2014, and I had never knew it existed, but I am glad I know now. This is truly a great indie game, and swordfighting game. The visuals and music are incredibly beautiful, and the gameplay is fantastic. There currently isn't a whole lot of content, and not a large community associated with this game (most likely because of it being in early-access, with not a lot of attention), but I'm sure any die-hard fan of swordfighting games will love this. As I have said, this is truly a great game.

reviewText:
I was Worried about purchasing this because i didn't think there was all that much too it and i would get bored within a few hours.  After finishing the tutorial and joining an online server I learned not only did i still have plenty to learn but how great the community is.

The game Is beautiful not only in its asthetics but also with the animations that all seem to flow really well together and in the heat of a duel it often looks like the 2 combatants are locked in dance rather than Combat.  The 4 different characters all have a Unique yet believable Fighting style which does suit certain sword types better than others but doesn't limit you.  (The first time you see a knight/samurai use a Rapier like it was a longsword you might laugh a bit.)  There is a character and sword combination for everyone.

There are no Upgrades or unlockables that change how you play or make you better the only thing that makes you more successful at the game is practice.  If you make a mistake you will know and most likely lose a large percentage of your health.

The community is friendly and if you are having trouble you could join pretty much any one of the servers and ask for help and get it.  Though there still are those few players who are venom (Those who are just rude and sore winners/losers) but for the majority Your duels will always end with Good fight!" "well played"  "GG" "That was a close fight!"  Its rare these days to see a community who are so willing to help each other the only other game I can think of with such a good community would be the PAYDAY community.

So yes After all this ranting I would Recommend this game to anyone whether or not your a sword fighting enthusiast or just want to enjoy a solid game (did i mention its built on the source engine?)"

reviewText:
This game fun, you play as sword people and fight other sword people.
Very interesting combat system with a good amount of mechanics which keeps fights fresh.
Currently the playerbase is solid but that's partially because this review was written during a F2P weekend. Unfortunately I've heard the community's pretty dead outside of these F2P weekends, but hopefully it'll pick up.
The community itself is really cool and the amount of customization available for the different characters is fantastic.
Steam Workshop swords and masks. Need I say more?

Ignore the negative reviews (most of the negative reviews were made during the first half of 2014 anyway, the game has long since changed then) and pick this up, but if you can, wait for a sale.
It's not exactly worth 15 bucks yet. 10, yeah. 15, eh.

Lots of swordfighting fun, especially if you've got your buddies.

reviewText:
I just simply love the depth of this game. Especially changing stance mid-attack, using feints, the swords clashing, it really gets intense.

I also love how the sword TYPE is the only weapon difference, with appearance not adding more than appearances. You get several types and character types. Each character has different moves and strengths/weaknesses. While each sword will modify attack speed and damage, with pros and cons.

So there is a lot of room to experiment with. I especially LOVE the depth of each type of gameplay. I've only played one vs one and found it easy to pick up and learn. It's definitely easy to pick up, but hard and rewarding to master.

reviewText: If you like fighting games and had a good time playing Bushido Blade back on the Playstation, this is a pretty good game in that lineage. Once I had that down and found a sword I was comfortable with I had a lot of fun dueling with a guy online for countless matches.\n\nIt would be nice if there were a bit more variation in the character customizations but hopefully that will be expanded. Unfortunately its really hard to get most of the gaming public interested in these minimalistic multiplayer-only games. Hopefully Blade Symphony will have a bright future as it is a really nice looking game and plays very smoothly.

What's neat Is all the unlocks are simply cosmetic, and if you can't afford a new sword yet there are plenty in the steam workshop that not only allow you to see the swod differently, but everyone else in the game sees the same model as you do.

reviewText:
A fast way to describe this game is like Jedi Academy meets Bushido Blade.

If that isn't enough then the best way I can describe playing this game is with a story of my first win in a Duel.
There are two kinds of servers you can play on, Free For All servers where you can practice and talk to other players or Dual servers where you go one on one in ranked matches.

Whilst you are cued to fight you watch however is currently playing. The game operates on a Winner stays on" system so a good player can stay on for dozens of matches. That was what was happening this time I was playing. The player who was controlling the ring was using a rapier
date: a sword that can break through a players guard easily and get a lot of low damage hits in. He had completely wiped the floor with me the first time we fought and so I got to watch him fight three other players before I got another try.\n\nI spent that time watching his tactics
recommended: the Rapier is great head on but does almost no damage if you try to swipe with it
hoursPlayed: so he was forcing the other player to come at him from the front. Either by throwing knives at them when they hung back or by diving in himself. In a sword clash or parry the Rapier will almost always come out on top so he was able to take people down with ease. Over the three fights I watch I figured out a strategy to take him down.\n\nI was using the Tone Death
voteText: the first Longsword you get in the game which is good for wide sweeping attacks. When the match started we bowed and then I started to circle him
helpfulPercent: trying to get in a position where I could get around and past his guard. He didn't seem to be expecting it when I finally came at him and
votesHelpful: instead of meeting him head on
votesTotal: rolled past his guard and brought my sword round in a wide horizontal swipe that took of a good sized chunk of his health.\n\nThe rest of the first round continued like that
votesFunny: with me chipping away at his health until he finally fell. The second round started differently
commentsCount: he came right in on the attack
column16: striking at me and putting me on the backfoot. I rolled away as fast as I could to get away from his attack. I managed to land a few hits hear and there but he was hurting me more than I was hurting him. I was going to lose if that kept up\n\nCharging up for a fast strike which would take of a huge chunk of my health if it landed
column17: he came around for a final strike. You can shuffle back instead of rolling
column18: it doesn't carry you as far but also doesn't leave you vulnerable to attack. So I started shuffling like a 50's singer and managed to dodge all three of his attacks along with the follow up. In the moment after his attack I brought my blade down it a heavy vertical strike and took of the rest of his health.\n\nHis body slumped to the floor and I sheathed my blade as I let out a breath I hadn't even known I was holding. I don't think I have ever felt happier at winning a game in my life."

reviewText: Oh, how I love this game. I have always been a fan of swordfighting games, but there haven't been many that I loved so much as this one. This game has been on Steam since May of 2014, and I had never knew it existed, but I am glad I know now. This is truly a great indie game, and swordfighting game. The visuals and music are incredibly beautiful, and the gameplay is fantastic. There currently isn't a whole lot of content, and not a large community associated with this game (most likely because of it being in early-access, with not a lot of attention), but I'm sure any die-hard fan of swordfighting games will love this. As I have said, this is truly a great game.

reviewText:
Truly one of the better unknown Games on Steam.
This Game is in an Early-Build and so it sometimes needs some improvements here and there, but the whole Gameplay is just extremely addicting.

Choose what Character you fight with!
Every Character has his own Attack Moves and so gives you a lot of space to try out different Combos.

Choose your Blade!
Every Blade has its' own attributes and properties, so find the weapon that suits you best!

Use your brain!
This Game gives us very much room to fight like we want to.
Do you think you can parry your enemys' attack? Or would you rather take the risk and try hitting him first?
Maybe you should do an evasion roll to move to the enemys' side.
How the battle results is all up to you!

Give it a Chance to grow!
By buying the Game, you give it a Chance to improve, get more players, get more content and much more!
The Game is one of the less known Games on Steam, but it's awesome for sure!

~Lynx

reviewText:
So far so good! The development team have done an excellent job so far, they have managed to create their own fighting/gameplay style which is very fun and strategic, allowing for your own tactics and methods to fight.

The different characters and weapons are all very interesting and offer variety, spoling its players.

While this is 100% multiplayer, I can imagine having a great time relaxing in an FFA server, talking and dueling people as I please.

The music and graphics are fantastic, while each level/map is gorgeous and well designed.

For what they are trying to do, the developers succeed, very, very well! However, I am left hoping that something a little deeper can be integrated in the gameplay, to add some of the magic from jedi knight 2. However, I'm sure the current system is already very thorough and I look forward to getting into this game properly!

reviewText:
First impressions: http://www.cublikefoot.com/blade-symphony-first-impressions/

Aww yeah, Blade Symphony! I've played this game far too much over the past few weeks, and I've gotta share my thoughts.

Blade Symphony is alright on its own. You can jump in and enjoy yourself, dueling against others and all, but the real fun is when you get a couple of friends to play it with you. I happen to have three other friends who also picked up the game, and boy is it fun. The true way to play the game is in a dueling fashion. You go up against another player in a one-on-one duel, which are very fun to do. There are three stances to take: fast, medium, and heavy. The heavier the attack, the more damage. I start off my fights with a heavy attack, quickly switching to fast attacks afterwards, then back to heavy after I've backed up a bit.

The sword fighting is excellently crafted, huge props to the work that went into it. We had a lot of fun stabbing each other for a good hour or two. After that, we took the game in a very different direction. The game has two modes: FFA and duel. You already know what duel is, but FFA is a bit different. FFA will take any of the duel maps and make it a large, open-world map for you and some buddies to mess around in. In this mode. you're able to parkour around the level, wall-running and such.

Due to the various parkour features, we ended up playing hide-and-seek for several hours. It sounds ridiculous, sure, but it was so good. Specifically, there was one map we spent a ton of time on. This map resembled a mall, and it was HUGE, much larger than any of the other maps. The parkour features allowed us to find some pretty interesting spots to camp out at, one of my favorites being the very top of the mall, higher than the top floor. The best spot, discovered by a friend of mine, happened to be above the elevator in this map. It was a small, black room that a few of us hid in whilst playing.

Blade Symphony is a fantastic game. It's still in development too, so there's much more to come, even in its already glorious state. I look forward to future additions to the game and highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Long story short, Blade Symphony is a fighting game and a good one at that.  But a review is a review, so I'll delve into it more.

Blade Symphony is a traditional fighting game except the main attraction of it is, as in the name, blades/swords.  Every match is a 2-out-of-3 match.  Your main weapon in this is a sword.  You can do the classic moves of any fighting game, such as grabbing, block-breacking, doing combos, etc.  Also, you do have a projectile, a smaller blade you could say.  But here is a main strength of the game: you cannot spam.  Instead, to throw you projectile, you have to charge the throw.  This is a good feature, especially for fighting game nuts like me since anybody who has played a fighting game online knows there are annoying" experiances.  Not with Blade Symphony.

Anyways
date: you have three techniques to your disposal: heavy
hoursPlayed: and fast.  Balanced is as it emplies

The downside is that you are extremely slow and any medicore-timed hit can have the opposition racking up combos and defeating you quickly.  You'll have to know your opponents moves and have good timing to use this technique to your advantage.  And last but not least is fast.  Fast is all about speed. Get a quick combo then move out of range

reviewText:
Blade Symphony is a complex sword fighting game with a friendly community that's not too big or too small, and is easy to learn, but hard to master.

PROS:
- Duel system built into the FFA mode
- 1v1, 2v1 and 2v2 duels
- a LOT of cool workshop items
- unique combo system
- Easy to use customization system
- Lag comp. system makes your ping seem to be 40-50 when its acualy 140-150

CONS:
- Not many servers
- No easy way to make your own workshop item

Get it its awesome
12/10

reviewText:
Great game about swordfighting!
You have 4 different characters, bunch of sword types (longsword, katana...) while able to do some customising, include workshop items.
While in battle you have 3 type stances, your attacks depends on your movement and it, different guarding, depends on sword.
You can choose any type/character at start, while playing you get notes that can be used to get other swords, skins.
Different gametypes, as Duel or Free For All (meanwhile in it you can challenge someone for fast duel).
Pretty easy to start, while many things to master.

reviewText:
I was Worried about purchasing this because i didn't think there was all that much too it and i would get bored within a few hours.  After finishing the tutorial and joining an online server I learned not only did i still have plenty to learn but how great the community is.

The game Is beautiful not only in its asthetics but also with the animations that all seem to flow really well together and in the heat of a duel it often looks like the 2 combatants are locked in dance rather than Combat.  The 4 different characters all have a Unique yet believable Fighting style which does suit certain sword types better than others but doesn't limit you.  (The first time you see a knight/samurai use a Rapier like it was a longsword you might laugh a bit.)  There is a character and sword combination for everyone.

There are no Upgrades or unlockables that change how you play or make you better the only thing that makes you more successful at the game is practice.  If you make a mistake you will know and most likely lose a large percentage of your health.

The community is friendly and if you are having trouble you could join pretty much any one of the servers and ask for help and get it.  Though there still are those few players who are venom (Those who are just rude and sore winners/losers) but for the majority Your duels will always end with Good fight!" "well played"  "GG" "That was a close fight!"  Its rare these days to see a community who are so willing to help each other the only other game I can think of with such a good community would be the PAYDAY community.

So yes After all this ranting I would Recommend this game to anyone whether or not your a sword fighting enthusiast or just want to enjoy a solid game (did i mention its built on the source engine?)"

reviewText:
Blade Symphony is an easy game to play, and difficult to master. With four character based sword-fighting techniques, mixed with multiple sword choices, and charater personalization options, this game is a must have for 3D Brawler fans. Theres a free roam option, as well as 1v1 and 2v2 duals, allowing you to show your skill against another opponent, or team up with your friends to see if you can work as a team.

Pros:
- Great Graphics even on lowest setting.
- Beautiful Music.
- Smooth Gameplay (for the stage that it's at in it's development.
- Steam Workshop Content is sure to have something you will use for character personalization.

Cons:
- Servers are desolate.
- Most Sword Choices are based around the katana sword.
- Default Button Layout is strenuous and non-sesoned PC players will stuggle with learning.

reviewText:
So far so good! The development team have done an excellent job so far, they have managed to create their own fighting/gameplay style which is very fun and strategic, allowing for your own tactics and methods to fight.

The different characters and weapons are all very interesting and offer variety, spoling its players.

While this is 100% multiplayer, I can imagine having a great time relaxing in an FFA server, talking and dueling people as I please.

The music and graphics are fantastic, while each level/map is gorgeous and well designed.

For what they are trying to do, the developers succeed, very, very well! However, I am left hoping that something a little deeper can be integrated in the gameplay, to add some of the magic from jedi knight 2. However, I'm sure the current system is already very thorough and I look forward to getting into this game properly!

reviewText:
Blade Symphony is a pure PVP multiplayer game where you challenge other players to see who has the superior swordsmanship. This game brings what most games failed to do.

Positive: Skill Based Combat. In this game you won't see some 80 lvl Swordmaster who will obliterate you with his mind. You won't see a man (or a woman) with Legendary sword of DESTRUCTION that will kill you even when you look at it. No Such Thing. And that is the best part. Player that just started playing has just as much chance of winning the game as the one that created the game. Only your skill matters nothing more. Every item, skin, mask or anything else is just cosmetic. You like big swords like in final fantasy? Here you go, buy that longsword for ingame money but don't expect it to be better or more damaging thatn the one you have right now.

Negative: This game is in early access stage, that means that there will be some problems. Like occasional lags, bugs and other annoying things. Currently there are only 4 classes and 5 weapon styles. Game doesn't have working AI for practice match (actually there is no AI for practice match). Matchmaking is non-existent. Some class balance issues. Automatic draw when time runs out etc.

Overall: I would give this game solid 8/10. Only 8 because it is still in early stage and lacks some crucial things. But it's not 6/10 because it has great potential and has innovative ideas of skill based combat. It is essentially what I look in games where wallet-warriors don't exist, or at least don't matter. Where every player plays at the best of his abbility. There are no sure-way fool-proof tactics to win the duel. This game will be a MUST BUY in a few months time. Right now it is good but mark my words, it will get exponentially better

reviewText:
This game CAN be fun, but it's absolute crap.
The hit box is all wrong, you can't seem to actually land a hit when your opponent is directly facing you, you think you've parried when you've actually taken a full blow right to the face.
The side strolls are sort of useful, but not that much as the hit box is slower than your actual body. So when you've sidestepped, you'll be hit.
When you do a roll, you'll be hit.
But when you jump... it's like your hit box becomes next to non-existant.... SERIOUSLY?!?!?

I've just played at LEAST 25 matches and only won 2 of them.
And it's not because I'm bad, but because my attacks never seem to land.
I give this game a good 2/10 for Engine but a 7/10 for Gameplay.
Graphix are neat, 8/10 as for the sound, some of their music have been inspired by popular songs. Once you listen to them, you'll recognize some of the intros. So, lack of insipiration. 6/10.

reviewText: so i've played this game for a few hours now and can honestly say that it's one of the best games ever played, but a factor that contributes to that is that im into swords and sword to sword combat and stuff like that. so for those other audiences that share the same factor as me, this game is definetly for you. now as for the game itself, i find it hard to believe that this only came out a few months ago. everything seems to run smoothly and i haven't run into any problems yet. the environments, though limited so far from what i've seen, are beautiful. the music fits really well, and the combat?? the amount of possibilities is too much to list. everything seems so fluid and well done. if there was a metal gear rising: revengeance online, i'd say this is the closest we'd get to it. so all in all, i give this game a 10/10 and highly reccomend it to competitve players, sword and sword combat fanatics, or anyone just looking for a change of pace from all the fps' that've come out lately. so as i said before, i highly reccomend you buy this game and support the developers so they can make the game even better than it already is.

reviewText:
A rather intuitive take on fighting games. Simply put:

- There are 3 stances of fighting (fast, balanced and heavy)
-Combos between styles can be strung together (shown visually in the bottom left I believe)
- There are 4 classes that each have their own merits
- There are a number of different types of weapons, each with their own benefits and of course recommended playstyle.


I really enjoyed this game, and if you liked games like Jedi Knight 2, you will love this game.

reviewText:
Beautiful Graphics - Yay!

Solid soundtrack - Yay!

Interesting take on swordplay - Yay!

Utterly stupid walking animations - Boo.

INSANE online learning curve - Boo.

Tutorial isnt exactly fully fleshed out, and doesnt prepare you for anything but bots - Boo.

Stylish characters - Yay!

Only 4 Characters to choose from - Boo.

Limited Customization options for Characters - Boo.

Nearly UNLIMITED customization options for you armory/playstyle - Yay!

Overall, Glaring problems with Sparkling Awesomes.

Dont buy it if you're a casual.

reviewText:
Best way to describe this game? If you ask me personally I would have to tell you that it's like a bunch of techno-ninjas and french duelists decided to gather together and kick ♥♥♥. Blade Symphony has really easy to handle controls, but is still challenging enough to be good at. (I'm nowhere near the good point yet.)

For $25 (USD) I bought a 2-pack of this game with its OST and within 48 hours of the purchase I've logged almost 10 hours of gameplay (This is huge since I tend to work almost all the time.) The gameplay is addicting and the community is full of good sports. I know I personally have received pointers numerous times.

Hope to see you in the arena!
~WinterCaxyl

reviewText: Sword Symphony is a Sword Fighting duel game set in a futuristic Japanese enviroment. The combat is unique, and the enviroments are beautiful and varied, along with polished user-interface. Although the combat may seem clunky and over whelming at first, you will soon find a unique playstyle that will fit the way you play. This game, however, is mainly about fighting, so variation in game modes is limited right now. I recommend buying this game, even if it's not on sale.

reviewText: This game is great for people like me that love swords, but don't have the cash to go out and buy a bunch, or learn proper swordsmanship. This fighting game feels like a swordsmanship simulator. The main emphasis of the game is upon blocking and parrying. The more skilled you are at blocking, parrying, or feinting an attack, the better you will be at this game. This is a game about skill, and it is definitely not a button masher. Also, the community for this game is highly supportive with new mods constantly coming out. This game helps me get out my need to just want to swing a weapon around like a maniac! Truly an amazing game.\n\nIt's true that some of the characters have swordsmanship styles that are unconventional, and probably wouldn't work in real life, it's still an amazing game to play when you wanna lay a beatdown on someone.

reviewText: This game requires some time to pick up various techniques during combat, becuase from my perspective when I bought this game was it might be a straight hack n slash with few move which that wasn't the case. The bulk of Blade Symphony's core fighting mechanics, duel mode stages, and  characters are well designed in general, but this makes the numerous flaws and incomplete areas that pop up all the more glaring.The tutorial itself gets things off to a poor start. While doing a decent job of explaining the basics of combat, it isn't complete. I also feel that the multiplayer aspect is also rather lackluster becuase it is focused mostly on dueling. I think this game has a chance to shine so I would still recommend it.\n

reviewText:
I have been eyeing this game for a while and was fortunate to get it in a bundle.

If you like swordplay, dueling, and heavily-skill based gameplay, then you will enjoy this game.

The aesthetics are fantastic with very detailed models, skins, and weapons. There is strong mod support for user-based content, adding a large variety to the customization potential. The music is very good at keeping you engaged in the extremely intense combat.

Although you will be primarily using the mouse, the controls can be very tricky to master without lots of practice, and the learning curve is moderate to high - depending on whether you are used to aggressive, all-out-offense gameplay (you will find this game very difficult if that is your preferred playstyle). The tutorial is very helpful and critical to understanding the mechanics of the game - playing practice fights with the AI can help you get a grasp of how each character + weapon works. The combos are not complex since you are just moving and using the mouse, but things like timing, switching stances mid combo, parrying, and dodging are important to balance and master.

The feedback for where and how your sword will strike is provided by a faint aura showing the weapon path. Manipulate where you will strike by using the mouse and also by moving around. You can do air attacks by jumping first.

There are different types of weapons, like katanas, longswords, and scimitars. Each weapon has different characteristics - for example: the katana is a fairly advanced weapon, inflicting heavy damage during counterattacks, but weaker in overall regular attacks. The longsword is pretty balanced and has a good blocking move.

You have three different stances, fast, balanced, and heavy - you can switch at will by rolling the mouse wheel. Using these stances, there is a rock-paper-scissors element that becomes integral to survival in this game. When two swords hit at the same time, a parry happens; however, different stances will override the parry, inflicting damage and creating a window for counterattacking. You can switch stances in the middle of your combos, and this makes the game very intense when you are trying to strategize and outmaneuver your opponent.

You can also cancel attacks to feint, and the tutorial does a good job of teaching you how to do this.

In the beginning, when you are first learning to play, be prepared to die. A lot. If you play roguelike games or Demon/Dark Souls, you should be well accustomed to dying - it will be the same here. Even when you are defeating the AI consistently and with excessive ease, you will still die when you play online. Just remember, its all part of the learning process.

I noticed that the connection time can get pretty lengthy, so that is something to consider - there is also no average wait timer, so you can't know for sure how long it will take to find/enter a match. There is also a lot of complaints about the card drop rate - if this is something you care about, I have found this game to have the most ridiculous drop rates. I still have 3 drops left, and others have reported only 1 drop in 8 hours. This isn't too big of a deal if you intend to play this regularly, but definitely be aware.

This game definitely takes a significant amount of skill, and I advise you to stay away if you intend to play casually or do not like games that are too difficult. Otherwise, give it a try, and you may find the challenge to be to your taste.

Recommend.

reviewText:
This game is simply amazing. The fighting styles, the techniques, the way in which it's not just continuing clicking on the same damn button as if it was Mortal Kombat or any fighting game that requires amazing combos to beat a person yet they use the same button. ANYWAYS, this game let's you have the fun of kicking someones butt. Despite how many times you're going to lose at the beginning, you'll begin to understand that this game is not easy at it seems to be.

Set aside from this, Blade Symphony is a third-person 3D swordfighting indie game which focuses primarly on multiplayer. It takes you to the basics of how swordsmen actually battle. Every attack has an opening so timing in this game is efficent or else you'll lose badly. You choose how you want to attack the person and which every attack, there's a different set of styles depending on the character you chose to play as. Advanced play has been primarily used by players who are masters in this game while the newcomers only know basic mechanics and so on. While the masters use all their flawless techniques, the newcomers would only not know how to time their attacks but also use basic fighting styles with little less combos that create openings for the masters. Many newcomers will not want to learn how to play the game therefore leading them to not only not knowing how to play it but losing in an instant to the masters or other players who had been learning this game for quite a while.

Other than that, this game like I said before, I love it. It's awesome. The community in this game is not so mean but at the same, not so friendly. So you could say it's in the middle. I see no reason to get bored of this game when it's gamemode is primarily on multiplayer with Steam Workshop items you could download from. Learning how to play something will increase your benefit of actually having a chance to win at a battle rather just going on full force with one blow.Well, have a nice time in this game and wish you the best of luck!

reviewText: The videos make the game look polished, finished, and requiring skill to play.  In reality, the game is nothing like that.  Yes, the graphics look good, but the rest of the game is pretty horrible.  They have you run through a tutorial on how the mechanics of the sword dueling goes.  They somewhat explain how the different styles work.  Then they throw you against AI to let you try them out.  Afterwards, you are left to go find a match and test your metal against other players.  Finding a match is a bear and because the matches support multiple contestants competing in a 1:1 battle, you usually find yourself sitting around spectating for a good portion.  Horrible matchmaking aside, that's not even the worst part.\n\nThe game mechanics you learn from the tutorial do not translate well against other human players.  Against AI who react and use dictated techniques the gameplay is fine.  But against users who can change styles, combo attacks, cancel actions, and can move anywhere of their own free will, it's VERY different.   Half the time you find yourself against people who are new (not their fault) and who rage over cheap moves"
date: which are really just the usage of the different "styles" to counter other styles (which is a game mechanic).  The other half are people who have realized that they can do things like cancel a combo at a certain time and instead choose a single move.  This means there's no consistency in the dueling.\n\nThe game sounds awesome in theory
recommended: but when they executed their ideas
hoursPlayed: they did so poorly and without proper testing (I assume
voteText: otherwise they released the game knowing of the issues and thought breaking the mechanics they set up was a good idea).  It's really not worth the money.  I picked the game up with a friend and even between the two of us
helpfulPercent: we had a hard time having fun with the game without mixing in other players.  The second you do
votesHelpful: the game becomes even more miserable."

reviewText:
Decent game, and I definitely had fun with my one-hour spent with it. The community -- that is, people who have stuck with the game and are experienced -- were very polite and helpful.

Unfortunately, I'd have to advise getting against this game because of the lack of a player-base. I had the luxury of playing during the Free Weekend which saw a big boost in player-population, but according to SteamCharts[0], the game's population always bounces back to pretty frighteningly-low levels after every sale/Freekend. And this isn't the type of game a noobie would want to get into, where only hardcore, experienced and dedicated people are playing it, ready to wipe the floor with someone who doesn't even know what they're doing yet. The accounts of other people also corroborate this problem (see the other reviews).

The forum community is also pretty toxic. So don't go there hoping to get a decent discussion about the game going.

Anyhow, as far as mechanics go, the swordplay felt good and balanced, and I really enjoyed out-witting some of my foes, as well as the prospect of further polishing-up my technique/understanding and participating in mind-games - but that's likely because I was mostly playing people who weren't part of the dedicated player-base. I do question how the character/weapon balance will pan-out in mid-to-high level play. That always becomes an issue in these types of games.

So yeah, I wouldn't spend money on this unless it was a $1 or something. Play it if it ever goes on for a Free Weekend again.

[0] http://steamcharts.com/app/225600

reviewText:
8/10

There is enough gameplay videos online to explain what the game is like and if you're reading this review you have probably already watched the intro video and probably don't need me to explain it to you. So i'll just get right into it

Really well done game in a competitive sense. The community is very helpful and alot of fun to play against. The variety in each different character style makes every encounter unique and really challanges you to attempt different combinations and learn your opponents movements to properly counter their playstyle and weapon choice.

I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a completely skill based close quarters combat game that requires a good combination of skill, reflexes and stratagy.

Buy and enjoy! We'd all love to see the community grow and florish.

See ya in the arena!

reviewText:
I bought the 2-pack hoping to play with a friend but had no end of problems getting multiplayer working.

The steam invites do nothing. If your friends host public servers you won't be able to find them in the server browser since servers are (apparently) LAN-only by default. After searching the forums I discovered that there is a workaround by running a bunch of commands from the game's developer console, but it really seems like more effort than it's worth.

I requested a refund but unfortunately I waited more than two weeks before installing it and Steam rejected the refund request.

reviewText: I played this just long enough to realise it's not for me. I can see that this would have a lot of potential but the downsides for me are that there's only one attack button (just with different stances), and they aren't kidding about only partial controller support - you cannot play this game without touching a keyboard (grab does not have a button by default), and you can't even navigate menus with the controller. I played most of the tutorial and jumped into an online game since there's no single player mode other than the tutorial. The online play experience seems to be mostly sitting around watching one really good guy slice people up until it's your turn to be destroyed and then go back to waiting. The one thing I did like about this is the level of character customisation, but it just wasn't fun to play. Overall I'd say Blade Symphony is like playing a brawler at home with a bunch of friends waiting for the loser to pass the controller to you - only without the friends. 3 out of 10, would not thrust.

reviewText:
PROS
+Nice feel and aestetics
+Fun and satisfying to win
+Plenty of variety in terms of weapons and armors
+Community is good in that they are always making new weapons and armors on the workshop
+Smooth and unique system of combat
+The majority of low rank people are nice

CONS
-Few servers
-If you wanted to, you could get to the highest rank via spamming certain classes
-If you or your opponenent is lagging you are dead in the water
-High rank players are very elitest and aren't very nice to newer players that could use the help of a high ranking friend
-Not very easy to learn or to master unless you want to spam your way to the top
-When you lose to a high ranking player that is also an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ about it, it makes you want to return the game
-Very small community
-Not a game where you can buy it, jump into a server, and be accepted by the higher rank players that practically own it
-If you are bad, people will call your moves cancer
-So few servers being used,if you wanted to avoid a specific ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, it would be nearly impossible
-Acheivment doesn't work

I would say that if you are not willing to play this game extremely competitively, and have a low tolerance to people being ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and bullies, do not get this game. If you play privately with a friend and one gets on a winning streak, it can ruin friendships. Spend your $9.99 on a better game to play with you friends.

reviewText:
Blade Symphony

To me, a solid sword fighting game that focuses on tactics was a breath of fresh air to me. Where you either charge in or bait your opponent into a false sense of security and superiority then you hit them with the cold, hard and unforgiving edge of reality via the blade you wield in your very capable hands.

You see that this game feels like other games but it still has its own identity.
Its not just some mindless hack and slash game. You gotta think, you gotta bait your opponent, you gotta find an opening before you strike or you could be on the receiving end of a painful and or deadly blow.
Its a fighting game that has you thinking about the next swing you make before you make it.
It forces you to be defensive when fighting a quick opponent and forces you to keep up momentum against a slower opponent. It punishes you with a swift and bitter defeat if you rush in too quick or too  carelessly. It gives you a quick win if you time your strikes just right and hit that massive tier 3 charge attack.

I love how Steam Workshop adds a variety of swords that you can use in combat as well as character personalization. You can actually wield an oversized pencil in combat. Think of how humiliating it would be for your opponent to lose to you. They wield badass swords, you wield a massive pencil and you dominate them. Just wow.

All in all this indie game is worth the money you put into it. If you still feel hesitant, pick it up during a sale. Beat up some swordsmen, customize your own and play. Download some new swords, practice those combos, charges and learn to parry.


Cheers

reviewText: Probably the best competitive melee combat game available at the moment, with a deep combo system that encourages mixing up your approach. I found earning cash to buy new pieces slow, and half the time it didn't even seem to give them to me (and this was not in FFA mode, which is not supposed to generate any cash). Luckily you are provided with every gameplay relevant item there is; the only things you're missing are skins. It also features Workshop support, giving you access to a variety of skins for free, and if you have the know-how to model a sword, you could put your own skins into the game.

reviewText:
I can't help but think this is a very niche game.

If it included any single player, story element, more tutorial, maybe.

But as it stands it's a multiplayer only, dead server with around 10 players still playing.

The combat is actually really good, and if I could connect to any one perhaps I'd enjoy it, but all I seem to be able to do is fight AI.

and that's it. no gear to change the characters except for visual changes, 5 sword styles + 4 characters styles = 20 total possible combinations

I wouldn't bother buying this game unless you have a small group of friends you want to play a decent fighter game with, that's the only reason I can think of bothering to get this game as it currently is
