reviewText:
As a newcomer to the Blade Symphony scene, it is best to describe the first impressions as that is what most games hook you in with. That being said, Blade Symphony is not like most games - it is a special gem that is being developed as we speak and with time it shall be worth much more than it is now; this I am sure of.

Blade Symphony is a 3D sword-fighting games with an abundance of swords to use. It is a splice between arena based combat and arcade style fighting with a limited amount of characters to choose from but a large supply of weapons to pick. There are two servers included within the online component of the game (the 'chapters' for single player use are currently being expanded upon).

There is the 'Free For All' or 'FFA' server in which all players roam around the map to either make as many enemies as they want or challenge others to duels. A good addition to this is the lack of interference from other players during duels - while roaming you can see others duel and you cannot interfere with them. Not to say you can't fight without challenges - during FFA, you can potentially fight all other players on the map at once.

There is also the 'Duel' servers. These contain a series of fighting stages on a map that you scroll through and 'queue' for in an effort to fight. When a second player also signs up for the board you then duel them in a one on one battle. Who ever is hosting can change the dueling modes to support 2 v 2 battles - the possibilities are varied!

On the single player side, a nice little tutorial is in place that, for now, is the only major showcase for AI in the single-player portion. Although I have not played with bots, they also exist for certain servers.

Combat is varied depending on the character chosen. In a similar fashion to Mortal Kombat, Tekken and Street Fighter, you have a choice of your character that you use (and in FFA you can switch when outside of battle). There are four characters each with their own fighting style. Pure, Phalanx, Ryoku and Judgement have different playstyles involved as well. While combat is usually high-paced among the visually lighter characters, don't be alarmed when fights take a slower pace. The ability to make your character 'walk' is as useful as the ability to 'run' on walls and manuever yourself.

Find yourself fighting an impatient 'fast' stance fighter? Switch to a 'heavy' or 'balanced' stance and take it slower by walking. Of course, using the fighter's to their best ability is done by using their innate techniques. It's better to take a heavy stance with Judgement than it is with Ryoku - but the game doesn't penalize you for taking it your own way. Finding your own technique among the four characters is part of the heart and challenge to this game. Don't be thrown off by the achievement statistics for winning one round. If you have the will to learn and the luck, you'll win your first round in no time.

A major part of the combat system to note is the combo system. Labeled as a 'multi-hit' the more attacks you link together in one string of movement adds to the counter; not taking damage helps. As you hit more than once the amount of damage dished out is increased, depending on the weapon. Characters don't have a set value for multi-hits but, because of the different speeds and styles, all can give out a different amount of comboed moves. Ryoku is a character that relies on the multi-hits when using weaker weapons because it increases the amount of damage he can give out. Judgement, however, relies less on this system, but, when a player uses it, it still benefits him in the same way it would Ryoku - it increases the output of his attack. With the fast paced battle taking place, it's imperative to complete multi-hits as necessary to win faster and mitigate the risk of losing.

The character design is hard to pinpoint - take sci-fi, steampunk, Eastern and Western influences and mash them together. That's a less eloquent way to describe the over-arching character costumes in appearence. It is harder to simply into a system when you get far enough to customize your character (described further down).

It's important to note that with so many factors involved, choosing from four characters is far from a simple game of rock-paper-scissors. Outcomes are reciprocated of player skill - at rare times is it up to your luck. If you learn from your mistakes quickly, this unforgiving dueling game can really shine and help.

This game is rewarding but such rewards are slow and take time and effort to attain them. You can customize and adorn your  four cool characters by adorning them with masks and skins - for a price. While there are NO MICROTRANSACTIONS in this game (a +), the system at which you gain the monetary units ('notes') can be seen as slow and tedious. No doubt, it's one of the minors in this upcoming game and it shouldn't deter you at all. The slow gain of 'notes' only impede character design and weapon unlocking. It rewards those who play the longest - or rather, the more you play, the more it pays. That said, it's a good way of differentiating the new comers from the more experienced sword masters. And while you can unlock more weapons, masks and skins you do not lose or gain an overbearing advantage over others. As long as you have control, the basic set of weapons are as deadly as the most brazen.

Capes, as of now, are also unlocked by completing special and secret objectives as you play. No doubt another rewarding factor for this game.

The characters?

Pure is a refined and acrobatic character - think Wushu fighting. With agile swordsman ship and experienced user skill she can be deadly - if you find yourself in a 2 v 2 against two skilled Pure users, you are definitely at a disadvantage. Pure is an offensive character that is best played by switching stances rapidly and soundly. Don't let up on your opponent lest they get the drop on you. Loosening the pressure is recommended however to open up the dueler's defenses when they lack an opening.

Ryoku is agile, fast but unrefined - he's great for stringing combos together and less useful at hitting hard. For him you'll want to build up your combos instead of vying for a one-hit kill. The fast paced action of this game suits him as you'll find yourself overcome if you fought these guys in a 2 v 2. The Scimitar is a fan-favorite for the Ryoku user as it allows them to (cheaply) build up 'multi-hits' and dole out punishment in the boss way the character defines.

Unless you are:

Phalanx. This guy. This guy is one I dislike - in a good way. He's a very plyable fencer that can strike from afar but will deal the necessary damage up close. He's also useful for stringing combos up and whipping an enemy into shape. With an experience player using him, he'll no doubt be the true challenge to beat. Watch out for Phalanx. They'll get you when you least expect it.

Judgement is a heavy hitting samurai. His default character, adorned in armor, has no trouble signifying how hard his experienced hand will come down upon his unlucky opponent. While he isn't as agile and swift as the other three, his recommended katana is useful for beating down the other. It's best to chalk Judgement up as one of the simpler to use. His slower speed allows for an easier string of combos if necessary by the less experienced player. He is, however, not a dominant combo chainer, his being the smaller out of all of them. Bulky and sluggish are in no way to describe him however. He is no doubt a tank and can take out a hit as well as dish them out - high damage with low speed if you look at it in technical terms.

In the end, Blade Symphony is no doubt a game for those who like swords, arcade fighting-games and arena based combat.

It is not a game for those who enjoy first person visuals, puzzle solving, platformers or role-playing games. Fast combat is not for slow players!

reviewText:
Blade Symphony is an excellent game, and is a prime example of how users and developers can stay in touch and collectively make the game what people want to play and how they want to see the material of the game advance and adapt. With full Workshop availability, customization and visuals, this allows for an extremely immersive and relatable experience.

As far as gameplay goes, the different types of weapons, characters, and skill sets make each matchup its own experience, and perpetuates the adventure and strategic value within the game! Figuring out different swords, characters and combos with each make for a fun game, and one that retains balance - an important concept to consider when it comes to fighting games!

The ranked system should be explained in more detail, but otherwise seems to be fair judgment. To put it simply, this game is an incredible experience, amazing detail to graphics and sword techniques in the real world, and makes for an interesting and fun, renewed experience that players are sure to love.

reviewText: Super fun. It's got a street-fighter vibe to it, or a 1v1 in Super Smash Bros. Except you're dueling with swords. I don't think it can really get any better than that. There are four characters with four very distinct personalities when it comes to fighting, and each can be manipulated to suit a certain fighting style, especially with weapon selection. All-in-all, it's a really fun game and the players seem like a nice enough community. The inclusion of Steam Workshop is an awesome plus too. Ever wanted to fight with the Master Sword? A lightsaber? A giant pencil? Here's your chance.

reviewText:
So about Blade Symphony. Let me start off by saying if it hadn't been for this free weekend I'd never have picked it up.. or rather never would have tried it, as I didn't pick it up.

I absolutely loathe the asian theme, the futuristic art-style, the over-the-top animations, the character design...basically the entire presentation of this game doesn't so much speak to me as it does shout Stay away. Far away".

However that is a personal preference and even though I'm essentially right in this I am also aware of the fact that there are people who have the audacity to be wrong and like this sort of stuff. Not much you can do about that.

But the game isn't just looks
date: so let's ignore those for now.\n\nThe fighting
recommended:
the heart of this game.. well it isn't bad. It is actually rather enjoyable to begin with.
It is however rather repetitive after a while. This is not - as some other people commenting here seem to think - due to a lack of content but rather due to a lack of input.
I actually like the fact that weapons are uniform across characters and I could do without the different character-traits as well. Purely cosmetic characters - making the outcome of a fight only about input-skill&speed rather than character attributes feels cleaner to me.

Input however is the problem.
You have far too little actual control to actually do something creative in your attacks
hoursPlayed: which means it all comes down to timing. Once you have ascertained that your timing is better than the opponents the fight is more or less over and will play out accordingly.\n\nI'm not going to go into balancing because I haven't played enough of it to actually notice - or care - and I've also limited myself to the Longsword
voteText: as it is the only of the weapons in this game I actually give a toss about. So while there might be balancing issues - there almost certainly are
helpfulPercent:
would be the first multiplayergame not to have those - I can't comment on those.

I can however comment on performance.
Some of the maps are rather mess as far as performance is concerned and - as with all melee games - if your ping rises or isn't stable it will have significant impact on your experience.
The performance-drops I noticed aren't significant enough to be blamed for getting defeated in combat (outside of really close matches on a very high skill-level which didn't really affect me all that much) but they are really irritating and a drag on the amount of joy the flow of combat delivers.

This flow sadly isn't all that great either. If your opponent is fast enough you can get locked-in by combo-attacks which basically drain most of your life before you are able to defend yourself (as you can't block mid-combo
votesHelpful: you can block it entirely or not at all in my experience). Similarly you can get yourself locked into the combo-animation and killed because you didn't hit the opponent but also were unable to respond to his attacks. Cancelling animations to perform new actions would obviously break the animation-style the game aims for

reviewText:
It is safe to say Blade Symphony is one of the best and most original fighting games of its time. However, it still has its problems like any other new game. Just because it is good doesn't mean it's perfect.
Pros:
-Many different fighting styles to suit each player.
-Clean, modern graphics
-Steam Workshop
-A few interesting moves (grappling, throwing Shurikens)
-(Mostly) Balanced  fighting system (No weapon or character is really too overpowered)

Cons:
-Very slight glitches and lag from time to time
- NO SINGLEPLAYER?
- Gets repetitive
- Many empty servers
- Grappling is WAY too slow.

If this was a finished game it would only deserve a 7.5/10 but considering how new the game is, and how it seems like a pretty fresh take on fighting games, I'd give it a 8/10. Defintely a buy for $7.50 during the Thanksgiving Sale, and maybe even a good buy for $15 if you have extra money and are just bored.

reviewText:
A great dueling game.
Already a fun experience, it can only get better with the implementations of more classes and weapon types.
A wider selection of maps/modes would also be good to see.

PROS:
Each class has its own variation of movements and available stance combos.
Different sword types allow a wider range of playstyles (ie: a Katana can benefit more from slashing moves, while a Foil is better suited for thrusts).
Easy to learn, hard to master.
Workshop customization.

CONS:
As with any heavy PvP game, lag is an important issue. A high ping makes the experience very annoying to deal with.
Could use more variety in terms of classes and sword types, but seeing as it is unfinished, this isn't a big issue.

reviewText: An amazing free-form fighting game.  There are elements of a traditional fighting game like frame traps, positioning, and combos, combined with the freedom and nuance of Jedi Academy.  I played a LOT of Jedi Academy back in the day and although I had a lot of fun with it, I can't honestly say that there wasn't a lot of randomness in how some fights played out.  Saber clashes weren't always consistent, and sometimes you just got lucky.  There's very little if any of that here.  The Fast/Balanced/Heavy stance system creates a very logical rock-paper-scissors type system to sword clashes.  In this game I can almost always say exactly things turned out the way they did and there's a logical way to combat different strategies.  It really does a great job of capturing the easy to learn
date: hard to master" environment that most competitive games strive for.  Speaking as both a traditional fighting game fan and a fan of Jedi Academy back in the day
recommended: this is a fantastic sword fighting game that I'm going to be putting a lot more hours into."
hoursPlayed: January 13, 2014

reviewText: This is an excellent game for hardcore skill junkies. It takes concentration, technique, strategie, precision, and calm thinking. Other than the fact that it requires more skill than just about every other game ever, it acts just like a brawler game. Customize you character, jump around the arena (I forgot to mention you can run on walls), and reduce your opponent to 0 HP. Each of the 4 playable characters have their own strengths and weaknesses. Judgement hits like a truck, but is very slow and easy to dodge. Phalanx hits hard and fast, but most of his attacks take hella accuracy. Pure and Ryoku are similar in the sense they both use kicks and flips in their basic attacks. Ryoku's attacks are very short range, making it easy for a decent Phalanx or Judgement to pick him off. Pure so far I've noticed has no downsides. Huge range, impossible to hit, lots of DPS. OP need nerf. Other than the fact that she's too strong, the game is well balanced, beautifully rendered, and very smooth to play. Absolutely worth the 15$.

reviewText:
First review I have done for a game.

While I like the idea, and do belive this game does a good job at execution, I strongly hope the developers are working on the competitive aspect of this game. When you play games like this, you want to become skilled, you want a stats that show you how well you are doing compared to others. While this game does offer that, it offers it in a very lackluster way. To a new player it is very hard to know what server is ranked and what isn't, causing most people to have a bad w/l ratio from the begining. Past that you can ONLY get elo from people in your divison, which is ridiculos. You can lose to someone 3 divions below you, or in return beat someone 3 divions above you and get nothing. Second off your rank is based on your world chart rank. Diamond is the top 2-10%, and master is the top 1%. This means that the longer the ladder is up, the harder it is to get division promotions, what sound like a good thing is acctualy a very horrible thing, as the game does something very stupid to help new players get diamond/master.

When you win/lose a game, you gain/lose mmr bassed on your expected" performence against that player. Lots of variables are used
hoursPlayed: their elo
voteText: your elo
helpfulPercent: and worse of all... time. If you play ranked constantly you will start gaining little to no elo
votesHelpful: making it impossible to rank up.\n\nThe ranked system is complete trash
votesTotal: you can go from oak-iron-diamond-master-oak all in one day
votesFunny: and it fels extremly unrewarding. It needs a massive improvment
commentsCount: along with a better matchmaking system. Overall its a solid game

As a new player getting into the game -- I'm lost. There is a quick tutorial that I tried that does a poor job of really teaching the mechanics. reviewText:
A long time ago i tried an idependent fighter called the showdown effect, it was a broken mess that relied on visual effects. When I saw Blade Symphony I thought it would be a similar disaster. But this was good because I was completely wrong about this game. I love games like legend of zelda and no more heroes, especially the sword mechanics, and the ones in this game... are brilliant. It's strategy on steroids. There are so many variations in how you can play that it's just... unbelievable. I heard the guy who made this game spent 8 years on it. To the creator of this game. If you see this then I want to say thank you. When someone shows dedication to making a game like this the rewards should be great. The graphics remind me of the kind of style in the infinity blade games. Before I give my final thoughts I'd like to acknowledge one more aspect. The music. It's a blast to listen to while fighting.

All of this combined made an epic setting for a video game that I haven't seen in years. This is innovative, and should not be overlooked.

10/10

reviewText:
Really cool game. In my honest opinion, it should be a bit cheaper, but its worth every cent: the swordfighting is good, the community has a honor code (kinda cool if you want to keep the  blind swordsman roleplaying thing alive) AAAAND the sometimes really soothing and chilling music.

If i had to say something bad about the game it is the fact that there is no real singleplayer experience, so you have to go on your own to perfect your technique. But hey, its not impossible, i have become a decent phalanx after a day, and i keep learning and learning from this.

Its just a matter of time that they release more classes and weapons, and I hope i get to see you over here!!

just a few things if you consider buying the game so you dont really lose your mind:

- Bear in mind that every character has 3 different sequences of combos, and each sequence can be exchanged by selecting the stances.
-Also, bear in mind the weapons used and their user. A phalanx doesnt do a lot of damage with say a jian, but give him a foil and he is deadly because of his fighting style. the same applies to judgement with the katana/longsword.
-Each weapon has a blocking mechanic. Katana has a standard block, jian has a intercept ability, foil has guard (weaker block, but ability to move)
- Bow with the B key, tease with the v key. 90% of the time i get a bow before a fight. Make sure you do that too to your oponent, it shows your respect. Also, dont throw ♥♥♥♥ at them when the battle starts, thats dishonorable.
- Keep your camera on the oponent AT ALL TIMES. watch his flaws, study quickly his openings. thats when you should strike with fast attacks.

Yeah, i hope to see you there, add me if this helped you decide to buy it and well play some rounds. See you at the dueling zone! ;)

reviewText: After watching Blade Symphony's trailer, I was very impressed by the environment's graphical presentation and fluid movements of the characters.  What's even better is it's not even out of Beta yet.  I had to try it out for myself so I immediately purchased this title.  Let me just say, it was even better playing it.  The graphics are heavenly, the gameplay is seemless, and the idea is great.  It's like playing a free-roam Soul Caliber game that allows you to challenge players on the fly.  Very easy to get a hang of the controls. A good amount a blade swing variations.  There are even different stances you can switch between while you are fighting in order to give you 2 slower, more powerful swings or 4 faster, less effective swings.  Brilliant arenas to fight in.  Great tutorial.  Very fun.\n\nI can't wait to see the final version of the game.  I totally recommend this game.

I don't know where to start with this game.

Blade Symphony is an fast-paced third-person action swordplay game that is challenging and hard to master but will keep you entertained to the fullest when climbing your way to the top.

This game has the best way of importing things from the workshop that I've seen since Garry's Mod. You can download different swords to use and masks to wear.
Speaking of swords and masks, the game offer many different types of swords to match your playstyle. From Longswords to Scimitars and Katanas to Rapiers, Blade Symphony really let's the player choose.
Aswell as having the many swords to choose from, you can choose one of four different characters each with their own unique way of fighting to suit you. The customization is endless in this game!
The graphics are where this game falls short. The game itself looks great but there's much more potential. For a game like Blade Symphony graphics are just as important as gameplay.

Blade Symphony has something I've never seen before in it's genre of game. It's hard to pinpoint what it is that makes this game so enjoyable. Maybe it's the online servers with hundreds of people to meet, duel and make friends with. Maybe it's how well it works and co-operates with it's players. Maybe it's just the whole game!

In closing, I think Blade Symphony is a fantastic and cutting edge game in it's genre that is focused towards the players enjoyment of the game. I really recommend you pick it up and try this game out, I sincerly think you'll like it.

reviewText:
A great dueling game.
Already a fun experience, it can only get better with the implementations of more classes and weapon types.
A wider selection of maps/modes would also be good to see.

PROS:
Each class has its own variation of movements and available stance combos.
Different sword types allow a wider range of playstyles (ie: a Katana can benefit more from slashing moves, while a Foil is better suited for thrusts).
Easy to learn, hard to master.
Workshop customization.

CONS:
As with any heavy PvP game, lag is an important issue. A high ping makes the experience very annoying to deal with.
Could use more variety in terms of classes and sword types, but seeing as it is unfinished, this isn't a big issue.

reviewText: An amazing free-form fighting game.  There are elements of a traditional fighting game like frame traps, positioning, and combos, combined with the freedom and nuance of Jedi Academy.  I played a LOT of Jedi Academy back in the day and although I had a lot of fun with it, I can't honestly say that there wasn't a lot of randomness in how some fights played out.  Saber clashes weren't always consistent, and sometimes you just got lucky.  There's very little if any of that here.  The Fast/Balanced/Heavy stance system creates a very logical rock-paper-scissors type system to sword clashes.  In this game I can almost always say exactly things turned out the way they did and there's a logical way to combat different strategies.  It really does a great job of capturing the easy to learn
date: hard to master" environment that most competitive games strive for.  Speaking as both a traditional fighting game fan and a fan of Jedi Academy back in the day
recommended: this is a fantastic sword fighting game that I'm going to be putting a lot more hours into."
hoursPlayed: January 13, 2014

reviewText:
Blade Symphony is still a young project, with lots of growing to do, but it's already a refreshing change of pace for weapon-based fighting games.

Not since Severance/Blade Of Darkness has a third person action melee title worked so hard to build strategic swordplay into a rewarding gameplay experience. Every encounter is uncertain but winnable, and the multilpe fighting styles are tuned for balance in very interesting and, to my knowledge, original ways.

There are a few games (Blade Symphony, Clang by Subatai and Sui Generis by Bare Mettle come to mind) currently in development that are seriously concerned about getting melee fighting RIGHT. I urge anyone who is interested in seeing interface breakthroughs from these projects make their way into larger titles (Elder Scrolls looms large in my mind) to support all of these specialist games as much as possible in order to enrich the landscape for everyone.
